BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases by people on very steep shady slopes, in particular adjacent to ridgelines above approximately 2500 m, as well as on little used shady slopes at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are rather rare but are difficult to recognise.
The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day, in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2500 m. There is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. This applies in particular in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The conditions are wintry at high altitude. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on shady slopes. Adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
Low and intermediate altitudes and very steep sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like.
In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing softening of the snowpack in particular on steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual strengthening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution. In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes above approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form at elevated altitudes. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep northwest, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2000 m and adjacent to ridgelines.
The somewhat older wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. In some regions strong northwesterly wind above the tree line.
Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack, in particular on very steep sunny slopes above approximately 2600 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution. In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists. The wind will be strong in some cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions a moderate avalanche danger will persist in some regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Very early morning: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
On very steep shady slopes the avalanches can be triggered in the old snow and reach medium size in isolated cases. This applies in particular in case of a large load. Even a small avalanche can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
At high altitudes and in high Alpine regions a moderate avalanche danger will be encountered in some localities.

In these regions hardly any more moist snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The conditions are wintry at high altitude. In particular adjacent to ridgelines snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Individual weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack on shady slopes.
Low and intermediate altitudes and very steep sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like. The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.
In all regions as well as in all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger at elevated altitudes is within the lower range of danger level 2 (moderate).

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The mostly small wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls at elevated altitudes. The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, on steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
In particular on steep slopes individual avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on weak layers. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
The weather will be partly cloudy. The weather conditions will give rise to moistening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming individual mostly small snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 2000 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, as well as on very steep sunny slopes. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. In high Alpine regions a little snow is lying. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger. These are to be found especially at high altitude. The weather conditions will give rise to moistening of the snowpack also at high altitude.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The conditions are favourable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The older wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines.

Only isolated gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall, in particular in the north. Over a wide area strong northwesterly wind above the tree line.

The snowpack will be in most cases stable.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Intermediate and high altitudes: Early and late morning: The snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions are favourable over a wide area. The wind will be strong in some cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Moist and wet avalanches and slab avalanches are the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation small moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2400 m, also in gullies and bowls in particular above approximately 1500 m, as well as on steep sunny slopes.
More recent wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,. The hard wind slabs are easy to recognise. Skiers can release avalanches only in isolated cases, including medium-sized ones. The avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather was mild. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases by people on very steep shady slopes, in particular in the vicinity of peaks above approximately 2600 m. The avalanche prone locations are very rare but are difficult to recognise.

In these regions hardly any more moist snow slides and avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the Prealps as well as at low altitude no snow is lying. Also in neighbouring regions less snow than usual is lying.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes below approximately 2600 m.
In very isolated cases weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The conditions are favourable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The older wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines.

Only isolated gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall, in particular in the north. Over a wide area strong northwesterly wind above the tree line.

The snowpack will be in most cases stable.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Intermediate and high altitudes: Early and late morning: The snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche conditions are favourable over a wide area. The wind will be strong in some cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry touring conditions in the morning, after a clear night, are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A mostly favourable avalanche situation will prevail. Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
Small avalanches: They can be released in near-surface layers by large loads. These avalanche prone locations are very rare and are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye. Transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack where hard layers are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack are unfavourable.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise in the early morning to slight moistening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m. As the temperature drops hardly any moist avalanches are possible in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the last eight days the weather was mild.
Steep south, west and southeast facing slopes,: Towards its surface, the snowpack is hard and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.
Below approximately 2000 m only a little snow is lying on south and southwest facing slopes. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
Along the border with Switzerland in some localities 5 cm of snow will fall in the evening above approximately 2000 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The mostly small wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist small and medium sized avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions will give rise to moistening of the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
In some regions only a little snow is lying.
